Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's testimony had inconsistencies and lacked corroboration
Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, lack of corroborating evidence
Legal_Provision: Section of IRPA relating to refugee protection and judicial review
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility, availability of state protection, internal flight alternative
Application_Error: Inconsistencies in testimony, lack of proof of state protection unavailability
Application_Factor: Credibility, state protection, internal flight alternative

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Threats related to refusal to participate in criminal activities
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Refusal to participate in criminal activities
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No evidence of nationwide influence by perpetrator
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Low risk at proposed internal relocation locations
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Non-state actor threat with limited geographic reach
Crimes.Threat_Source: Hugo Sanchez (employer and alleged drug trafficker)
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, due to refusal to engage in illegal acts
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to prove lack of state protection or internal flight alternative
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Alleged threats, no official reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claimant did not report incidents or justify avoidance of authorities
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections 96 and 97(1), Refugee Convention

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Violence and threats by non-state actor
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Large geographic size of Mexico enabling relocation
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High at incident location, but not nationwide
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Reasonable possibility of internal relocation to avoid risk
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted due to association/refusal to cooperate
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to prove inability to seek protection or relocate
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Self-reported threats and assault, no police reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim not substantiated with credible evidence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Asylum claim involving internal relocation feasibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Availability of internal flight alternative and access to state protection
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Refugee Convention
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Immigration and Refugee Board decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Limited weight given to Mexican lawyer's letter due to timing
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove no safe internal relocation option
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Failure to report to authorities undermines credibility
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by drug trafficker
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Size and diversity of Mexico, lack of evidence on Sanchez’s national reach
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Did not report incidents or attempt relocation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavit, legal opinion letter
Crimes.Authority: Federal Court, Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim based on fear of persecution due to criminal involvement
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Refugee Convention, Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Threats due to refusal to participate in drug trafficking
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Availability of internal relocation and lack of state protection failure

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining the applicants were not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear not objectively well-founded; insufficient evidence to prove lack of state protection or internal flight alternative
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Persecution fears from a gang and a municipal employee in Venezuela
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Availability of state protection and internal flight alternative
Crimes.Application_Error: None found by the Court
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified as ignored; rather, evidence was deemed insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable possibility standard, not balance of probabilities
Crimes.Application_Factor: Failure to prove lack of state protection or impossibility of internal relocation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failing to report threats to police
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 97, IRPA (persons in need of protection)
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Extortion by gang and harassment by municipal employee
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Denial of refugee status by IRB
Crimes.Credibility: Partially undermined due to lack of reporting

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to provide sufficient evidence to rebut state protection presumption
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 101(1)(a), IRPA (burden of proof on claimant)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Anonymous police complaint without identifying details
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of Federal Court over IRB decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of detail and verification in anonymous complaint
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Undermined due to inconsistencies
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugee or protected person
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of question or overturning of decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Clear and convincing evidence to rebut state protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Anonymous complaint insufficient to prove lack of state protection

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repetition of demands, abuse of public office
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No physical harm reported, limited geographic threat
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Moderate to high, depending on enforcement context
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Personalized based on prior employment dispute
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Partially compromised by lack of corroboration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to inconsistencies and lack of reporting
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to refugee determination

Legal_Issue: Credibility findings, breach of natural justice
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in testimony regarding husband's detention and statements to immigration officials
Evidence_Type: Oral testimony, statements to immigration officials
Legal_Provision: Definition of Convention refugee: well-founded fear of persecution
Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim dismissal
Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution, natural justice
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed, no certification of serious question of general importance

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Violation_Type: Failure to establish well-founded fear of persecution or risk of torture
Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution from authorities and Sikh terrorists in India; reported threats by Sikh men and questioning by Indian authorities
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent and implausible testimony, including doubts about delays and actions
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Credibility concerns, inconsistencies in narrative, lack of corroboration
Credibility_Assessment: Board found testimony inconsistent and implausible; Court found no patently unreasonable error
Decision_Outcome: Board dismissed refugee claim; judicial review application dismissed
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Board's decision upheld
Relief_Sought: Refugee protection and successful judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of Board's decision and referral for re-determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution or risk of torture under sections 96 and 97
Standard_of_Review: Patently unreasonable standard for credibility findings
Decision_Rationale: Board's credibility assessment was reasonable; no reviewable error identified
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding that the Applicant had a viable Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) in Kiev
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no question certified
Credibility_Assessment: The Applicant's claims of anti-Semitic persecution were not fully credible; issues found to be localized and personal in nature
Evidence_Type: Evidence regarding localized threats, state protection in Kiev, resource limitations affecting all citizens, personal vendetta by Shevchuk
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of a viable Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) in Kiev
Legal_Standard: Risk of persecution must exist in every part of the home country
Application_Factor: Personalized threat, lack of systemic anti-Semitism, availability of state protection in Kiev
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed due to viable IFA in Kiev

Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 18.1(4)(d) of the Federal Court Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to persecution in Mexico; Refugee Division found internal flight alternative to be reasonable; evidence about police presence in Toluca and psychological impact was not addressed
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider critical evidence; lack of proper assessment of relocation expectation
Evidence_Used: Applicant's evidence regarding police vehicles in Toluca, psychological impact of persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Refugee Division did not address key evidence on safety concerns outside Mexico City
Decision_Outcome: Original decision rejected claim based on internal flight alternative
Outcome: Decision set aside; case remitted for reconsideration by a new panel
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review; reassessment of refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious possibility of persecution; reasonableness of internal flight alternative
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness; correctness for questions of law
Decision_Rationale: It was unreasonable to expect relocation without assessing risks in Toluca; failure to consider evidence rendered decision perversely
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution in Pakistan; Board found documents likely fraudulent with inconsistencies and contradictions; issues deemed local, not national
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – claim for protection, not residency status
Misrepresentation_Element: Yes – documentation likely forged, common practice in Pakistan
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of Immigration and Refugee Board decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Contradictions in testimony, lack of credible evidence supporting national-level persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Negative – applicant's credibility undermined by inconsistencies and potential forgery
Decision_Outcome: Internal flight alternative (IFA) found available; refugee claim denied
Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugee, protection from removal
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious possibility of persecution on balance of probabilities
Decision_Rationale: Persecution risk was local, not nationwide; applicant failed to prove no safe internal flight alternative
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicant faced persecution by state agents (OJI) in Costa Rica; seeking help from these agents would have increased danger; lawyer attempted to involve Ombudsman without success
Procedural_Issue: RPD's determination that applicant did not adequately seek state protection
Evidence_Used: Evidence of persecution by state agents, attempt to engage Ombudsman
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee based on lack of state protection
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a new RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Presumption of state protection can be rebutted with clear and convincing evidence of state's inability to protect
Decision_Rationale: Seeking protection from persecuting state agents would have increased risk; efforts through Ombudsman failed; RPD's finding was unreasonable under the circumstances
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Alabadleh overstayed his visa and applied for Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA), claiming risk if returned to Gaza.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer did not consider child's interests as part of s.97 assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Evidence presented in PRRA application regarding personal risk
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence linking applicant’s circumstances to child's welfare
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment of personal risk under s.97 IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: PRRA officers assess personal risk, not humanitarian factors like child's interests; such considerations fall under s.25 H&C applications. Risk assessment under s.97 was adequate based on available evidence.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-compliance with removal and risk assessment provisions
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant challenged PRRA decision on grounds of inadequate risk assessment and failure to consider child's interests.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: New evidence submitted during judicial review was excluded because it was not before the PRRA officer
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence regarding impact on child and personalized risk details
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed, no legal question certified
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of a broader legal issue (refused)
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment of personal risk under s.97 IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: PRRA officer acted reasonably by focusing on personal risk under s.97; humanitarian considerations such as child's interests are outside PRRA scope and belong in s.25 applications. No reviewable error found.

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer breached principles of fairness by not updating the application after a two-year delay
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 113(a)
Crimes.Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness occurred; PRRA decision stands
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Alleged new risk was deemed implausible given prior RPD findings
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of new or updated evidence from applicant
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 113(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Claim of increased personal risk upon return to home country
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant's failure to provide updated information during the delay
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to update application with new circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None — no new evidence was submitted
Crimes.Legal_Standard: PRRA officers must assess new evidence but are not required to solicit updates
Crimes.Application_Factor: Two-year processing delay, applicant inaction
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: PRRA application rejected due to lack of new evidence

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period

Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Tovar remained in Canada after her visa expired while pursuing protection claims
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable — violation based on status, not false statements

Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA application, lack of updated submissions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide new evidence supporting continued stay
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Increased risk claim unsubstantiated
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal based on PRRA application
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of a question for appeal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness for PRRA, correctness for jurisdictional issues
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No procedural unfairness; applicant had opportunity to update but did not

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order

Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Tovar failed to depart Canada after final removal order was issued
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged oral deferral request not documented or acknowledged

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim of oral deferral request not accepted
Crimes.Outcome: Removal order remains valid and enforceable
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Set aside removal order or defer removal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No duty to defer without clear request or practical impediment

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Suspected fraudulent marriage for immigration benefit

Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution upon return due to changed personal circumstances
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to provide new evidence supporting genuine relationship
Crimes.Application_Error: Did not disclose or substantiate marital status changes
Crimes.Legal_Standard: PRRA officers assess risk based on submitted evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of denied refugee claim and lack of cooperation
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Suspicion of sham marriage not proven but contributed to credibility concerns

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged breach of procedural fairness in PRRA and removal processes
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether PRRA and removal officers respected natural justice
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, principles of procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer relied on existing record; no duty to seek new evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistent claims and lack of follow-up
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Officers must act fairly but are not required to prompt applicants for updates
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Two-year delay, alleged oral deferral request
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of updated submissions or formal deferral request
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles applied to immigration decisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CBSA and IRCC maintained decisions were procedurally fair
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Written PRRA application, removal interview notes
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 113(a), IRPA; common law procedural fairness

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Violation_Type: Failure to establish well-founded fear of persecution
Application_Facts: Applicants delayed claiming refugee status for seven weeks, citing hope for peace; Board found this inconsistent with testimony; no documentary evidence supporting claims of older Tamils being arrested in 2000
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence regarding conditions in Sri Lanka in 2000
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No documentation supporting arrest of older Tamils in 2000
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicants not credible due to inconsistencies and implausible explanation for delay
Remedy_Sought: Certification of question of general importance
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution or risk of cruel treatment under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Delay in claiming refugee status undermined subjective fear; lack of credible and supporting evidence; Board's findings within acceptable range of outcomes

Crime_Name: Costs Assessment in Intellectual Property Litigation
Legal_Issue: Assessment of costs under Column IV vs. Column III of Tariff B
Procedural_Stage: Trial, Post-trial motion for cost assessment
Evidence_Assessment: Complexity of legal issues, business significance, conduct during litigation, settlement offer timing
Decision_Outcome: Costs assessed under Column III, double costs awarded after settlement offer date
Burden_of_Proof: Plasticair to justify higher cost column based on complexity and importance
Credibility_Factor: Delays caused by Plasticair weighed against their claim for higher costs
Legal_Rule: Costs discretion under Federal Court Rules considering result, complexity, settlement offers, and conduct
Grounds_for_Claim: High stakes, technical complexity, importance of case
Outcome_on_Merits: Both claims dismissed, but costs awarded to Plasticair
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of legal issues, duration of trial, expert and travel expenses, settlement offer timeline
Legal_Framework: Tariff B of the Federal Court Rules
Defendant_Response: M.K. Plastics defended against infringement and asserted invalidity
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, expert reports, procedural history
Remedy_Requested: Costs under Column IV of Tariff B
Outcome: Costs awarded under Column III, double costs post-settlement offer, reasonable expenses approved
Legal_Provision: Federal Court Rules, SOR/98-106, Tariff B

Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 111 of the Veterans Review and Appeal Board Act
Governing_Law: Veterans Review and Appeal Board Act
Application_Facts: MacKay applied for a veteran's disability pension, claiming neck disability due to a 1958 military accident. His application was repeatedly denied.
Procedural_Issue: VRAB refused to reconsider VAB's decision based on new medical evidence without proper assessment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider uncontradicted and credible new medical evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Dr. Murdoch's report was uncontradicted and credible
Decision_Outcome: VRAB's refusal to reconsider was found to be a jurisdictional error
Outcome: Federal Court allowed MacKay's application for judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of VAB's decision by VRAB
Legal_Standard_Applied: Criteria for 'new evidence' under s. 111 and proper application of s. 3 and s. 39
Decision_Rationale: VRAB committed a jurisdictional error by not accepting Dr. Murdoch's evidence and failing to apply s. 3 and s. 39 correctly

Risk_Type: Risk due to state protection failure

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Risk_Nature: Failure of legal system to intervene

Burden_of_Proof: On applicant, but not properly evaluated
Legal_Rule: Child vulnerabilities must be considered under IRPA

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Provide Necessities of Life
Defendant_Response: Board relied on general country conditions

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether failure to disclose change in marital status constitutes misrepresentation under s. 27(1)(e)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of ignorance rejected
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Signed immigration documents declaring accuracy of information
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to update marital status before entry
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Duty to disclose material facts regardless of intent
Crimes.Application_Error: Non-disclosure of marriage
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation includes non-disclosure of material facts
Crimes.Application_Factor: Marriage occurred shortly before immigration
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False declaration through omission in official forms

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant married before landing but did not report it
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking entry as single individual
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with disclosure requirements
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of proof of notification of marital change
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Ignorance not accepted as defense
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to disclose material fact constitutes misrepresentation regardless of intent

Risk_Nature: Due to criminal activity in country
Due to high crime rates in Mexico

Application_Facts: Fled Mexico due to gang threats
Residency_Compliance: Lawfully present in Canada for claim
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence of continued threat

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion of refugee claimant despite negative danger opinion
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the Minister of Public Safety exclude a refugee claimant after a negative danger opinion by the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not applicable (decision based on legal interpretation, not credibility)
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Conviction record, asylum application documents
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention, IRPA sections 98, 101, 112
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Seriousness of the crime committed abroad
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Seriousness of the crime (murder conviction abroad)
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Federal Court, Immigration and Refugee Board
Crimes.Application_Error: None found
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Article 1F(b) exclusion under the Refugee Convention
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature and seriousness of the foreign conviction
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or immigration documents

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Refugee claimant with prior foreign conviction
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Seriousness of the crime, foreign conviction for violent offense
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Rehabilitation and current dangerousness considered but deemed irrelevant
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Assessed as not requiring individualized evaluation due to crime seriousness
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Potential threat due to past violent crime
Crimes.Threat_Source: Individual with history of violent criminal conduct
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Foreign court conviction, immigration and refugee claim documents
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged; conviction accepted as fact
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable (focus on exclusion, not sentencing)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention, IRPA sections 98, 101, 112

Application_Facts: Applicant Qureshi denied citizenship due to alleged failure to meet residency requirements and procedural fairness concerns regarding an anonymous letter.
Residency_Compliance: Judge found non-compliance with three-year residency requirement within four-year period
Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of procedural fairness due to reliance on anonymous letter
Evidence_Used: Anonymous letter, applicant's evidence with inconsistencies
Credibility_Assessment: Judge assessed applicant's credibility as lacking due to inconsistent evidence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Disclosure of prejudicial information for procedural fairness; Residency under s. 5(1)(c)
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness; Reasonableness for residency determination
Decision_Rationale: Procedural fairness upheld because contents of anonymous letter were disclosed and applicant responded; Residency requirement not met based on inconsistent evidence
